articles.headline: Widening Split in Europe on the Virtue of Austerity
articles.snippet: Countries that have backed Germany’s call for fiscal discipline elsewhere are realizing austerity could make it harder for them to pay down their own debts.
articles.abstract: Countries that have backed Germany’s call for fiscal discipline elsewhere are realizing austerity could make it harder for them to pay down their own debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Throughout Europe’s long debt crisis, Germany has prescribed the same strong remedy to its troubled neighbors: a stiff dose of fiscal discipline.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Say, Can You Make Phone Calls on That Camera?
articles.snippet: As users embrace iPhones and other smartphones as cameras, attachments have made it easier to get professional-looking photos.
articles.abstract: As users embrace iPhones and other smartphones as cameras, attachments have made it easier to get professional-looking photos.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As the technology that powers smartphone cameras has steadily improved, the point-and-shoot has become an endangered species. Taking pictures with a smartphone has become so popular, it even has its own name: iPhoneography, or smartphoneography for those with non-Apple mobile phones.

articles.headline: As New Graduates Return to Nest, Economy Also Feels the Pain
articles.snippet: Young Americans who can afford to move out have decided to wait until getting on more solid footing, and their prudence is depriving the economy of a lot of potential activity.
articles.abstract: Young Americans who can afford to move out have decided to wait until getting on more solid footing, and their prudence is depriving the economy of a lot of potential activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like most of her friends, Hollis Romanelli graduated from college last May and promptly moved back in with her parents.

articles.headline: The Smokers’ Surcharge
articles.snippet: Some companies are starting to penalize employees who smoke or are obese by raising their health insurance costs.
articles.abstract: Some companies are starting to penalize employees who smoke or are obese by raising their health insurance costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: More and more employers are demanding that workers who smoke, are overweight or have high cholesterol shoulder a greater share of their health care costs, a shift toward penalizing employees with unhealthy lifestyles rather than rewarding good habits.

articles.headline: U.S. Hones Warnings to Egypt as Military Stalls Transition
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has expressed concern that the failure to move to civilian control could undermine the defining revolt of the Arab Spring.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has expressed concern that the failure to move to civilian control could undermine the defining revolt of the Arab Spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Brazen attempts by Egypt’s interim military rulers to hold on to power long after elections have elicited a sharp reaction domestically and for the first time have prompted Washington to warn about the potential for new unrest.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Route Proposals May Ease an Oil Pipeline Bottleneck
articles.snippet: With the timing, and perhaps the future, of the Keystone XL pipeline project now uncertain, alternatives to the hotly contested project have begun emerging.
articles.abstract: With the timing, and perhaps the future, of the Keystone XL pipeline project now uncertain, alternatives to the hotly contested project have begun emerging.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — With the timing, and perhaps the future, of the Keystone XL pipeline project from Canada’s oil sands to the Gulf Coast now uncertain, two alternatives to the hotly contested project have begun emerging.

articles.headline: U.S. to Review Cases Seeking Deportations
articles.snippet: The Department of Homeland Security is making changes that are aimed at speeding up deportations of convicted criminals and halting those of many illegal immigrants with no criminal record.
articles.abstract: The Department of Homeland Security is making changes that are aimed at speeding up deportations of convicted criminals and halting those of many illegal immigrants with no criminal record.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security will begin a review on Thursday of all deportation cases before the immigration courts and start a nationwide training program for enforcement agents and prosecuting lawyers, with the goal of speeding deportations of convicted criminals and halting those of many illegal immigrants with no criminal record.

articles.headline: Billions Lost by Olympus May Be Tied to Criminals
articles.snippet: Japanese officials say at least $4.9 billion is unaccounted for at Olympus and are looking into whether much of it went to companies with links to organized crime.
articles.abstract: Japanese officials say at least $4.9 billion is unaccounted for at Olympus and are looking into whether much of it went to companies with links to organized crime.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese officials say that at least $4.9 billion is unaccounted for in a financial scandal at Olympus and are investigating whether much of that money went to companies with links to organized crime.

articles.headline: Star Manager Giving Up Legg Mason Fund
articles.snippet: Bill Miller helped found Legg Mason in 1982 and it made him a legend on Wall Street, but the volatility after 2006 hit the fund hard.
articles.abstract: Bill Miller helped found Legg Mason in 1982 and it made him a legend on Wall Street, but the volatility after 2006 hit the fund hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Miller, a legendary mutual fund manager, said Thursday he was stepping down from the Legg Mason fund that had long made him a star on Wall Street until the volatile years after 2006 brought his fund and his stellar track record hurtling to earth.

articles.headline: Words of a Euro Doomsayer Have New Resonance
articles.snippet: Bernard Connolly’s proposition that foisting a common currency upon many disparate nation states would end in ruin is getting a much wider hearing.
articles.abstract: Bernard Connolly’s proposition that foisting a common currency upon many disparate nation states would end in ruin is getting a much wider hearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The euro zone was crumbling, just as he had long predicted, yet Bernard Connolly, Europe’s most persistent prophet of doom, still faced a skeptical audience.
